SFI is committed to minimizing accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration process at the Stephenville Plant. Facility management is involved in the design, operation, and maintenance of the system. SFI employees at all levels have been involved in the development of the PSM and RMP programs. Management has committed to working with local agencies and the community to educate the public regarding the hazards of ammonia and to ensure a safe workplace and surrounding community.

Schreiber Foods, Inc. (SFI) - Headquartered in Green Bay, Wisconsin, Schreiber Foods is the
largest employee-owned dairy company in the world. Schreiber sells its products - which include cream cheese, natural cheese, processed cheese, and yogurt - to leading retailers, restaurants, distributors, and food manufacturers around the world. Schreiber has more than 30 manufacturing and distribution facilities globally.

The SFI  Stephenville Plant employs approximately 551 people. The SFI plant uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration of the products in storage as well as for cooling of manufacturing process lines. Anhydrous ammonia is subject to EPA regulation under 40 CFR 68, Accidental Release Risk.

Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.
Pursuant to the RMP regulations (40 CFR 68) and the Process Safety Management (PSM)
regulations, SFI has developed a comprehensive PSM written program to protect our employees and the surrounding community from exposure to hazardous chemicals onsite. The facility completed an initial process hazards analysis (PHAs) for ammonia using the industry standard HAZOP Analysis developed through the International Institute for Ammonia Refrigeration. The most recent PHA revalidations were completed in 2021 using the HAZOP methodology. The original and revalidation PHAs were completed using technical and operations staff from the Stephenville Plant as well as experienced facilitators.
The PHAs reviewed operational, human factors, and facility siting issues relative to the design of the refrigeration system, and recommendations were made, as appropriate, to address these concerns. SFI's implementation of the PSM program includes employee education in the hazards of ammonia and measures that can be used to reduce employee and community exposure to accidental releases of ammonia. The plans include preventive maintenance programs (mechanical integrity) for the ammonia system, and a program for both pre-startup safety reviews and management of c

hanges (MOC) to the system. The program also includes specific requirements for safe work practices (such
as safe approaches to welding and similar hot work) and safety requirements for contractors who may be hired to work on the system.

The program also has a procedure for conducting compliance audits to ensure the PSM program is being implemented at the Stephenville facility.
The PSM written program incorporates the Plant's emergency response plan and places
special emphasis on handling accidental releases of hazardous chemicals and coordination of
emergency response with local fire departments and other emergency response organizations.

Many of SFI's refrigeration and maintenance personnel have completed 24-hour HAZWOPER
HAZMAT technician level training program. This training includes topics such as classification
systems and hazard identification; ammonia spill control and containment; respiratory protection; air monitoring instrumentation; proper personal protective equipment; medical monitoring; and proper termination procedures for emergency response activities. The facility conducts annual HAZWOPER refresher training to keep employees current and comfortable with their responsibilities under the plan using classroom discussion and response to mock emergency scenarios.

As part of the RMP requirements, SFI undertook a review of the potential offsite consequences of the accidental release of the largest vessel in the systems. Although such a release is highly unlikely, the regulation requires this review.
SFI stores and uses anhydrous ammonia on site for refrigeration of products in storage as well as for cooling of manufacturing process lines. Ammonia is used for its excellent energy efficiency and flexibility, in addition to benefits to employee safety. Ammonia at the facility is kept entirely within the refrigeration system, much as the refrigerant in your car air-conditioner.
